item.title: Plane War
item.description:
Plane War Game Program

Introduction

I always think that interest is the best teacher. It is easier for us to learn what we are interested in. Especially after learning object-oriented and class programming, I have always wanted to create something, and games are undoubtedly a good choice. First of all because I like playing games very much. Secondly, because the game has very good visual effects. I believe everyone wants to have a game of their own. I chose to program an airplane war game.

Create a Graphics Window

  • Load Pygame model

    Pygame is a cross-platform set of Python modules designed for writing video games. It includes computer graphics and sound libraries designed to be used with the Python programming language.

    import pygame
from pygame import *

  • Initialization and exit of the game

    Method: Description
    pygame.init() initialize all imported pygame modules, use it before another modules.
    pygame.quit() uninitialize all pygame modules, use it when you want exit the game. 
    def main():
    pygame.init()

if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()
    pygame.quit()

  • Create the main game window

    pygame has a special method pygame.display for creating and managing game windows

    Method Description
    pygame.display.set_mode() Initialize the game display window
    pygame.display.update() Refresh the screen content display 
        set_mode(size=(0, 0), flags=0, depth=0, display=0, vsync=0) -> Surface

    This function will create a display Surface. The arguments passed in are requests for a display type. The actual created display will be the best possible match supported by the system.

    Parameter

    • The size argument is a pair of numbers representing the width and height.
    • The flags argument is a collection of additional options.
    • The depth argument represents the number of bits to use for color.

    Here are the display flags you will want to choose from:

    pygame.FULLSCREEN    create a fullscreen display
pygame.DOUBLEBUF     recommended for HWSURFACE or OPENGL
pygame.HWSURFACE     hardware accelerated, only in FULLSCREEN
pygame.OPENGL        create an OpenGL-renderable display
pygame.RESIZABLE     display window should be sizeable
pygame.NOFRAME       display window will have no border or controls
pygame.SCALED        resolution depends on desktop size and scale graphics
pygame.SHOWN         window is opened in visible mode (default)
pygame.HIDDEN        window is opened in hidden mode

    def main():
    pygame.init()
    # Set the windows
    screen = pygame.display.set_mode(size=(480, 700), flags=0)

if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()
    pygame.quit()

  • Game loop

    • In order to ensure that the game program does not exit immediately after it is started, a game loop is usually added to the game program
    • The so-called game loop is an infinite loop
    • Below the code for creating the game window, add an infinite loop
    def main():
    pygame.init()
    # Set the windows
    screen = pygame.display.set_mode(size=(480, 700), flags=0)
    while True:
        pygame.display.update()

  • Add Events Listener

    When we run the program, we find that the window has appeared, but we cannot manipulate the window, or even close the window. Therefore, we should add an Events Listener to control the closing of the window.

    # Set Events Listener
for events in pygame.event.get():
    if events.type == pygame.QUIT:
        pygame.quit()
        exit()

Draw image

In the game, most of the game elements that can be seen are images

  • We need to follow three steps to display the images in windows:

    • Use pygame.image.load() to load image data
    • Call the blit method to draw the image to the specified position
    • Call the pygame.display.update() method to update the display of the entire screen

  • Background and Player

    def main():
    pygame.init()
    # Set the windows
    screen = pygame.display.set_mode(size=(480, 700), flags=0)
    background = pygame.image.load("images/background.png")
    player = pygame.image.load("images/me1.png")
    while True:
        # Set Events Listener
        for events in pygame.event.get():
            if events.type == pygame.QUIT:
                pygame.quit()
                exit()
        screen.blit(background, (0, 0))
        screen.blit(player, ((480 - 102) / 2, 500))
        pygame.display.update()
    • NOTE: Please blit the Background first, then blit the Player so that the Player is on top of the Background

Control Plane and Keyboard Listener

Now, we have Plane, but we can’t control Plane yet. To make Plane move, we need to use pygame.key.get_pressed() to get Keyboard Listener

  • Keyboard Listener

    Before setting the Keyboard Listener, we need to give the aircraft a Speed parameter to control the distance the aircraft moves each time.

        speed = 1
    # Set Keyboard Listener
    key_pressed = pygame.key.get_pressed()

    # Set UP
    if key_pressed[K_w] or key_pressed[K_UP]:
        y -= speed
        print("W")

    # Set DOWN
    if key_pressed[K_s] or key_pressed[K_DOWN]:
        y += speed

    # Set LEFT
    if key_pressed[K_a] or key_pressed[K_LEFT]:
        x -= speed

    # Set RIGHT
    if key_pressed[K_d] or key_pressed[K_RIGHT]:
        x += speed

    # Set SPACE
    if key_pressed[K_SPACE]:
        pass

    Now, we can control Plane through the mouse. However, we found that if the operation is improper, Plane will easily fly out of Windows, which is something we don’t want to see. Therefore, we have to set the Plane control to prevent the aircraft from flying out of Windows.

        # Set Keyboard Listener
    key_pressed = pygame.key.get_pressed()

    # Set UP
    if key_pressed[K_w] or key_pressed[K_UP]:
        if 0 <= y - speed <= 700 - 126:
            y -= speed
        else:
            y = 0

    # Set DOWN
    if key_pressed[K_s] or key_pressed[K_DOWN]:
        if 0 <= y + speed <= 700 - 126:
            y += speed
        else:
            y = 700 - 126

    # Set LEFT
    if key_pressed[K_a] or key_pressed[K_LEFT]:
        if 0 <= x - speed <= 480 - 102:
            x -= speed
        else:
            x = 0

    # Set RIGHT
    if key_pressed[K_d] or key_pressed[K_RIGHT]:
        if 0 <= x + speed <= 480 - 102:
            x += speed
        else:
            x = 480 - 102

    # Set SPACE
    if key_pressed[K_SPACE]:
        pass

  • Persistence of vision

    We set the speed to 10, and then run, we will find that Plane is moving too fast, and the CPU usage is also high. This is because Python loops too quickly every time, so it loops too many times in a second.

    When an object is moving fast, when the image seen by the human eye disappears, the human eye can continue to retain its image. The image is about 0.1-0.4 seconds. This phenomenon is called Persistence of vision.

    According to the Persistence of vision, we can reduce the number of infinite loops, thereby slowing down the movement speed of the Plane and reducing the CPU usage of the program.

    There are two way to reduce the number of infinite loops:

    • Use pygame.time.Clock() to keep the game running slower than the given ticks per second.
    clock = pygame.time.Clock()
while True:
    clock.tick(60)
    • Use time module to sleep loop.
    import time

while True:
    time.sleep(0.01)

Object-Oriented Programming

item.title: CSE 385 Database
item.description:
• 2021-01-28

    • Create a Table

      CREATE TABLE dbo.tblFriends(
    friendId            INT                     NOT NULL        PRIMARY KEY                     IDENTITY,
    firstName           VARCHAR(20)             NOT NULL,
    lastName            VARCHAR(20)             NOT NULL,
    age                 INT                     NOT NULL        DEFAULT(-1),
    phoneNumber         VARCHAR(20)             NOT NULL        DEFAULT('(***) ***-****'),
    [address]           VARCHAR(200)            NULL            DEFAULT(NULL)
);

    • Version 1: Creates many transactions

      INSERT INTO tblFriends (firstName, lastName, age, phoneNumber, [address])       VALUES('A', 'A', 22, 'A', 'A')
INSERT INTO tblFriends (firstName, lastName, age, phoneNumber)                  VALUES ('B', 'B', 22, 'B')
INSERT INTO tblFriends (firstName, lastName, age)                               VALUES ('C', 'C', 22)
INSERT INTO tblFriends (firstName, lastName)                                    VALUES ('D', 'D')
/*
INSERT INTO tblFriends (firstName)VALUES ('E')
Cannot insert the value NULL into column 'lastName', table 'Example.dbo.tblFriends'; 
column does not allow nulls. INSERT fails.
The statement has been terminated.
*/

    • Version 2: Creates 1 transaction

      INSERT INTO tblFriends (firstName, lastName, age, phoneNumber, [address])	
VALUES 
    ('a', 'a', 22, 'a', 'a'),
    ('b', 'b', 22, 'b', 'b'),
    ('c', 'c', 22, 'c', 'c'),
    ('d', 'd', 22, 'd', 'd')

    • READ file

      CarData.txt

      CREATE TABLE tblCars (
Id		INT			NOT NULL		IDENTITY (1, 1)	PRIMARY KEY,
vin		VARCHAR(17)	NOT NULL,
make	VARCHAR(30)	NOT NULL,
model	VARCHAR(30)	NOT NULL,
year	INT			NOT NULL,
);
      
BULK INSERT tblCars
FROM 'c:\temp\CarData.txt'
WITH (
    FIRSTROW = 2,
    ROWTERMINATOR = '\n',
    FIELDTERMINATOR = '\t',
    KEEPIDENTITY
);
SELECT * FROM tblCars WHERE make = 'Honda';  -- 29 records 

UPDATE tblCars SET make = 'HONDA' WHERE make = 'Honda';
SELECT * FROM tblCars WHERE make = 'Honda';

    • DROP and TRUNCATE TABLE

      • DROP

        DROP will drop (delete) the whole structure in one go i.e. it removes the named elements of the schema. By using this command the existence of the whole table is finished or say lost.

          DROP TABLE IF EXISTS tblCars

      • TRUNCATE

        TRUNCATE use to delete all the rows of a relation (table) in one go. With the help of TRUNCATE command we cant delete the single row.

          TRUNCATE TABLE tblCars;

item.title: Markdown Guide
item.description:
• Overview
  • Headings
  • Bold
  • Italic
  • Bold and Italic
  • Blockquotes
  • Lists
  • Horizontal Rules
  • Links
  • Images
  • Reference

Overview

Nearly all Markdown applications support the basic syntax outlined in John Grubers original design document. There are minor variations and discrepancies between Markdown processors those are noted inline wherever possible.

Headings

To create a heading, add number signs (#) in front of a word or phrase. The number of number signs you use should correspond to the heading level. For example, to create a heading level three (), use three number signs (e.g., ### My Header).

# Heading level 1 # #

## Heading level 2 ## ##

### Heading level 3 ### ###

#### Heading level 4 #### ####

##### Heading level 5 ##### #####

###### Heading level 6 ###### ######

Bold

To bold text, add two asterisks or underscores before and after a word or phrase. To bold the middle of a word for emphasis, add two asterisks without spaces around the letters

I just love **bold text**.

I just love bold text.

Love**is**bold

Loveisbold

Italic

To italicize text, add one asterisk or underscore before and after a word or phrase. To italicize the middle of a word for emphasis, add one asterisk without spaces around the letters.

Italicized text is the *cat's meow*.

Italicized text is the cat’s meow.

A*cat*meow

Acatmeow

Bold and Italic

To emphasize text with bold and italics at the same time, add three asterisks or underscores before and after a word or phrase. To bold and italicize the middle of a word for emphasis, add three asterisks without spaces around the letters.

This text is ***really important***.

This text is really important.

This is really***very***important text.

This is reallyveryimportant text.

Blockquotes

Blockquotes can be nested. Add a » in front of the paragraph you want to nest.

> Blockquotes
>
>> Blockquotes

Blockquotes

Blockquotes

> #### The quarterly results look great!
>
> - Revenue was off the chart.
> - Profits were higher than ever.
>
>  *Everything* is going according to **plan**.

The quarterly results look great!

  • Revenue was off the chart.
  • Profits were higher than ever.

Everything is going according to plan.

Lists

You can organize items into ordered and unordered lists.

Ordered Lists

To create an ordered list, add line items with numbers followed by periods. The numbers dont have to be in numerical order, but the list should start with the number one.

1. First item
2. Second item
3. Third item
    1. Indented item
    2. Indented item
4. Fourth item
  1. First item
  2. Second item
  3. Third item
    1. Indented item
    2. Indented item
  4. Fourth item

Unordered Lists

To create an unordered list, add dashes (-), asterisks (*), or plus signs (+) in front of line items. Indent one or more items to create a nested list.

- First item
- Second item
- Third item
    - Indented item
    - Indented item
- Fourth item
  • First item
  • Second item
  • Third item
    • Indented item
    • Indented item
  • Fourth item

Horizontal Rules

To create a horizontal rule, use three or more asterisks (***), dashes (---), or underscores (___) on a line by themselves.

***

---

_________________

Links

To create a link, enclose the link text in brackets (e.g., [Duck Duck Go]) and then follow it immediately with the URL in parentheses (e.g., (https://eason366.github.io/)).

[Back to Home Page](https://eason366.github.io/)

Back to [Home](https://eason366.github.io/) Page

Back to Home Page

Back to Home Page

##Adding Titles

You can optionally add a title for a link. This will appear as a tooltip when the user hovers over the link. To add a title, enclose it in parentheses after the URL.

[Back to Home Page](https://eason366.github.io/ "Back to Eason's Hugo Blog Home Page")

Back to [Home](https://eason366.github.io/ "Back to Eason's Hugo Blog Home Page") Page

Back to Home Page

Back to Home Page

Images

Reference

https://www.markdownguide.org/basic-syntax/

item.title: How to Upload my Blog to Github
item.description:
How to Upload my Blog to Github

Upload local server

 hugo server -t hugo-theme-stack --buildDrafts

Use http://localhost:1313/ to check.

Upload to my Github

	hugo --theme=hugo-theme-stack --baseUrl="https://Eason366.github.io/" --buildDrafts
	#Create web page
	cd public
	#Enter the public folder
	git add .
	git commit -m "commit"
	git push -u origin master

Use https://eason366.github.io/ to check.

Creat a new Blog

hugo new post/#BlogName.md

item.title: Regression Analysis on Wine Qualit
item.description:
• Introduction
  • Exploratory Analysis
  • Model Choose
  • Model Assumption
  • Model and Analysis
  • Conclusion
  • References
  • Appendix

Introduction

The study of interest was with regards to the factors that affect the quality of red wine. The data used was obtained from https://archive.ics.uci.edu/ml/machine-learning-databases/wine-quality/. For the study, quality was therefore used as the dependent variable, while independent variables used were; residual sugar, chlorides, total sulfur dioxide, pH, sulphates, and alcohol. To identify if the independent variables were significant predictors of quality, multiple linear regression was carried out using R.

Exploratory Analysis

Exploratory analysis involved carrying out descriptive statistics for all the variables of interest in the study. For the variable residual sugar, the minimum residual sugar was 0.9 while the maximum was 15.50. The mean residual sugar was 2.539 and the median value was 2.20. For the variable chlorides, the minimum chloride was 0.012 while the maximum was 0.611. The mean chloride level was 0.087 and the median value was 0.079. For the variable total sulfur dioxide, the minimum value was 6 while the maximum was 289. The mean total sulfur dioxide was 46.47 and the median value was 38. For the variable pH, the minimum value was 2.74 while the maximum was 4.01. The mean pH was 3.311 and the median value was 3.31. For the variable sulphates, the minimum value was 0.33 while the maximum was 2. The mean for sulphate was 0.6581 and the median value was 0.62. For the variable alcohol, the minimum value was 8.40 while the maximum was 14.90. The mean for alcohol was 10.42 and the median value was 10.20. For the variable quality, the minimum value was 3 while the maximum was 8. The mean value for quality was 5.638 while the median was 6.00.

Model Choose

Now that we have 11 independent variables, we decide to use the stepwise algorithm for model choose. Among all models, the model with the smallest AIC is selected for fitting. After calculation, finally select the seven independent variables chlorides, alcohol, total.sulfur.dioxide, sulphates, pH, volatile.acidity, free.sulfur.dioxide to predict our dependent variable, quality.

Model Assumption

Before regression analysis could be carried out, the data was analyzed to investigate its suitability for carrying out multiple regression analysis. To start with, the data was checked for multicollinearity by computing correlations among all the independent variables. The results of the correlation showed that there was no multicollinearity as no two independent variables had strong correlations with each other. To check if residuals are normally distributed, a QQ plot was also computed in R. The QQ plot for residuals did not show much deviation from the normal. Homoscedasticity assumption was also checked by making a plot of residuals vs predicted values. The plot showed that the assumption was met as values were randomly distributed across the fit line (Illowsky, 2013). The model assumptions were mostly met and therefore multiple regression could be carried out in R.

Model and Analysis

Multiple linear regression was computed with quality as the dependent variable and residual sugar, chlorides, total sulfur dioxide, pH, sulphates, and alcohol as the independent variables. The overall regression model was statistically significant, F(6,1592) =121.6, p value<0.0001. This means that a majority of the independent variables are statistically significant predictors of quality. The t analysis of individual variables showed that the variables chlorides (t=-6.827, p<0.001), total sulfur dioxide (t=-5.213, p<0.001), pH (t=-6.561, p<0.001), sulphates (t=10.726, p<0.001), and alcohol (t=18.641=, p<0.001) are significant predictors of quality. Residual sugar was not a statistically significant predictor of quality, t= 0.661, p=0.509. The slope coefficient of chlorides was equal to -2.766. This indicates that quality decreases by 2.766 for every 1 increase in the amount of chlorides. The slope coefficient of pH was equal to -0.7588. This indicates that quality decreases by 0.7588 for every 1 increase in the pH. The slope coefficient of total sulfur dioxide was equal to -0.0027888. This indicates that quality decreases by 0.003 for every 1 increase in the total sulfur dioxide. The slope coefficient of alcohol was equal to 0.3207. This indicates that quality increases by 0.3207 for every 1 increase in the amount of alcohol. The slope coefficient of sulphates was equal to 1.18. This indicates that quality increases by 1.18 for every 1 increase in the amount of alcohol.

Conclusion

In conclusion, the results of the multiple linear regression showed that that the variables chlorides, total sulfur dioxide, pH, sulphates, and alcohol are significant predictors of quality. One can therefore use the model to predict the quality of wine based on these variables.

References

Illowsky, B., Dean, S., & Illowsky, B. (2013). Introductory statistics. OpenStax.

Appendix

knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE)
library(dplyr)
library(GGally)
library(leaps)

# https://archive.ics.uci.edu/ml/machine-learning-databases/wine-quality/
df <- read.csv("winequality-red.csv", sep=";")
summary(df)

step(lm(quality~ chlorides +alcohol+residual.sugar+total.sulfur.dioxide
        +sulphates+pH+fixed.acidity+volatile.acidity+citric.acid
        +free.sulfur.dioxide+density , data = df), direction = "both")
